item.title: ::pickup
item.dc:creator: @RuneX-Gaming RuneX-Gaming
item.description:
@RuneX-Gaming wrote:

[quote=“facundo, post:6, topic:262145”]when you want to spawn a item, you have to say the following:

::pickup ##### #####.

The ##### are for item code, for example, if you want the item 995, you have to say 00995, because you have to write always 5 numbers, so 3 of 995, and 2 of 0s to complete the 5 numbers, then, make a space, and write the quantity of the item you want.[/quote]

All you acctually have to put for item ID 995 (Money) is;

::pickup 0995 1

::pickup (ITEM ID) (AMOUNT)

  • RuneX -

Hope this helped you.

Read full topic

item.title: ::pickup
item.dc:creator: @facundo facundo
item.description:
@facundo wrote:

when you want to spawn a item, you have to say the following:

::pickup ##### #####.

The ##### are for item code, for example, if you want the item 995, you have to say 00995, because you have to write always 5 numbers, so 3 of 995, and 2 of 0s to complete the 5 numbers, then, make a space, and write the quantity of the item you want.

Hope this helped you.

Good Luck.

Facundo.

Read full topic

item.title: ::pickup
item.dc:creator: @xx_qwertyuiop_xx xx qwertyuiop xx
item.description:
@xx_qwertyuiop_xx wrote:

I prefer allowing the arguments of the command to have variable lengths.

if(command.startsWith("pickup"))
{
    String[] args = command.split(" ");
    try
    {
        int itemId = Integer.parseInt(args[1]);
        int itemAmount = Integer.parseInt(args[2]);
        if(itemId > 0 || itemId < 20000)
        {
            addItem(itemId, itemAmount);
        }
        else
        {
            sendMessage("Invalid item id.");
        }
    }
    catch(NumberFormatException nf)
    {
        sendMessage("Usage: ::pickup #### #");
    }
}

Read full topic
